Using this, we then have that $$\begin{alignat*}{2} \operatorname{\mathbf{In}}(\mathcal{M}_i+\mathcal{M}_j) \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}(\mathcal{M}_i+\mathcal{M}_j) &=\;&& (\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i \cup (\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}M_j \smallsetminus \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i)) \cap (\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i \cup \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_j) \quad \text{by \ref{eq:input_of_sum} and \ref{eq:output_of_sum}} \\ &= &&(\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i) \\ &&& \cup (\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_j) \\ &&& \cup ((\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}M_j \smallsetminus \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i) \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i) \\ &&& \cup ((\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}M_j \smallsetminus \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i) \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_j) \qquad \text{by distributivity of $\cap$ over $\cup$} \\ &= &&\emptyset \cup \emptyset \cup \emptyset \cup \emptyset \\ &= &&\emptyset \end{alignat*}$$ That each of the intersections in the distributive expansion is empty is easily verified: ùêàùêß‚Ñ≥i‚à©ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i and (ùêàùêßMj‚àñùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i)‚à©ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥j)(\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}M_j \smallsetminus \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i) \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_j) are both empty as a consequence of direct modules having non-overlapping inputs and outputs. (ùêàùêßMj‚àñùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i)‚à©ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i(\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}M_j \smallsetminus \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i) \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i must be empty since a member of ùêàùêßMJ\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}M_J that is not in ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i can‚Äôt also be in ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i. Finally, ùêàùêß‚Ñ≥i‚à©ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥j=‚àÖ\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i\cap\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_j=\emptyset was a stipulation made when defining the ordered sum of ‚Ñ≥i\mathcal{M}_i and ‚Ñ≥j\mathcal{M}_j.

Equation perhaps requires a little explication in order to be comprehended.

Suppose we are given some value ùê±\mathbf{x} in ùêëA‚à™(C‚àñB)\mathbf{R}^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B)}, the domain of f*gf\ast g. We can describe (f*g)(ùê±)‚ààùêëB‚à™D(f\ast g)(\mathbf{x})\in\mathbf{R}^{ B\cup D} by describing the way to compute how (f*g)(ùê±)(f\ast g)(\mathbf{x}) maps each y‚ààB‚à™Dy\in B\cup D into ùêë\mathbf{R}.

First suppose y‚ààBy\in B. Then we need only look at the first component in the union on the right-hand side of ‚Äînamely, f‚àòœÄA‚à™(C‚àñB)‚ÜíAf\circ\pi^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B)\to A}. The projection œÄA‚à™(C‚àñB)‚ÜíA(ùê±)=ùê±|A\pi^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B)\to A}(\mathbf{x}) = \mathbf{x}|A of ùê±\mathbf{x} to ùêëA\mathbf{R}^A tells us that we need consider only the coordinates of ùê±\mathbf{x} that correspond to members of AA. Once we have a vector in ùêëA\mathbf{R}^A, we can apply the function ff to obtain a value in ùêëB\mathbf{R}^B. This is all we need, since yy is in BB.

Now suppose y‚ààDy\in D. Here we need to look at the somewhat more complicated second component of the right-hand side of , that is, g‚àò(œÄA‚à™(C‚àñB)‚ÜíC‚àñB‚à™(œÄB‚ÜíC‚à©B‚àòf‚àòœÄA‚à™(C‚àñB)‚ÜíA))g\circ(\pi^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B) \to C\smallsetminus B} \cup (\pi^{ B\to C\cap B}\circ f\circ \pi^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B)\to A})). Since g:ùêëC‚ÜíùêëDg: \mathbf{R}^C\to\mathbf{R}^D, we need to feed gg some value in ùêëC\mathbf{R}^C to obtain a mapping to ùêë\mathbf{R} of values (such as yy) in DD. But ùê±\mathbf{x} is in ùêëA‚à™(C‚àñB)\mathbf{R}^{A\cup(C\smallsetminus B)}, so ùê±\mathbf{x} only tells how values in CC that aren‚Äôt also in BB are mapped. The mapping for these values corresponds to the projection œÄA‚à™(C‚àñB)‚ÜíC‚àñB(ùê±)=ùê±|(C‚àñB)\pi^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B) \to C\smallsetminus B}(\mathbf{x}) = \mathbf{x}|(C\smallsetminus B), a value in ùêëC‚àñB\mathbf{R}^{C\smallsetminus B}. To find the portion of the mapping we need that belongs to ùêëC‚à©B\mathbf{R}^{C\cap B}, we look at œÄB‚ÜíC‚à©B‚àòf‚àòœÄA‚à™(C‚àñB)‚ÜíA\pi^{ B\to C\cap B}\circ f\circ \pi^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B)\to A}. As we have just seen, f‚àòœÄA‚à™(C‚àñB)‚ÜíAf\circ \pi^{ A\cup (C\smallsetminus B)\to A} maps ùê±\mathbf{x} to a member of ùêëB\mathbf{R}^B. Then we can apply the projection œÄB‚ÜíC‚à©B\pi^{ B\to C\cap B} to obtain a member of ùêëC‚à©B\mathbf{R}^{C\cap B}. Taking the union of the components in ùêëC‚àñB\mathbf{R}^{C\smallsetminus B} and ùêëC‚à©B\mathbf{R}^{C\cap B} gives us a value in ùêëC\mathbf{R}^C, to which we can apply function gg. The result is a function in ùêëD\mathbf{R}^D telling how all values (such as yy) in DD are mapped.

General ordered sum

We now generalize the notion of an ordered sum of two direct modules to the ordered sum of any finite number of direct modules.

Suppose we have an ordered collection (‚Ñ≥1,‚Ñ≥2,‚Ä¶,‚Ñ≥n)(\mathcal{M}_1, \mathcal{M}_2, \dots, \mathcal{M}_n) of direct modules. As is the case with all direct modules, ùêàùêß‚Ñ≥i‚à©ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i=‚àÖ\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i\cap\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i=\emptyset for all ii. Further, assume that ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i‚à™ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥j=‚àÖ\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i\cup\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_j=\emptyset for all i‚â†ji\neq j, and that ùêàùêß‚Ñ≥i‚à©ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥j=‚àÖ\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i\cap\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_j=\emptyset whenever i<ji<j. Then we define the ordered sum ‚àëi=1n‚Ñ≥i\sum_{i=1}^n\mathcal{M}_i recursively as follows: $$\begin{alignat}{2} \sum_{i=1}^k\mathcal{M}_i &= M_1 && \qquad\text{for $k=1$} \notag \\ \sum_{i=1}^k\mathcal{M}_i &= \sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\mathcal{M}_i + \mathcal{M}_k && \qquad \text{for $1<k\leq n$}\label{eq:recursive_module_sum} \end{alignat}$$

Things are not quite as simple as this, however, since we must show that the ordered sum given on the right-hand side of is always defined. Specifically, we must show that $$\begin{align} \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\mathcal{M}_i \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_k &= \emptyset \label{eq:general_sum_disjoint_outputs} \\ \intertext{and} \operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\mathcal{M}_i \cap \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_k &= \emptyset. \label{eq:general_sum_general_condition} \end{align}$$

But it easily follows by induction from equation that ùêéùêÆùê≠‚àëi=1k‚àí1‚Ñ≥i=‚ãÉi=1k‚àí1ùêéùêÆùê≠‚Ñ≥i,\begin{equation*} \operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\mathcal{M}_i = \bigcup_{i=1}^{k-1}\operatorname{\mathbf{Out}}\mathcal{M}_i, \end{equation*} and easily follows from this, the distributivity of ‚à©\cap over ‚à™\cup, and the assumption that the outputs of the modules are pairwise disjoint.

To prove , we first observe that it follows immediately from that ùêàùêß(‚Ñ≥i+‚Ñ≥j)‚äÜùêàùêß‚Ñ≥i‚à™ùêàùêßMj\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}(\mathcal{M}_i+\mathcal{M}_j) \subseteq \operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i \cup \operatorname{\mathbf{In}}M_j, and from this it is easy to show by induction that ùêàùêß‚àëi=1k‚àí1‚Ñ≥i‚äÜ‚ãÉi=1k‚àí1ùêàùêß‚Ñ≥i.\begin{equation} \operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}\mathcal{M}_i \subseteq \bigcup_{i=1}^{k-1}\operatorname{\mathbf{In}}\mathcal{M}_i. \end{equation} Since a stipulation in defining the ordered sum of modules was that output of each module in the ordered collection is disjoint from the inputs of each module occuring earlier in the ordering, in light of the distributivity of ‚à©\cap over ‚à™\cup, the desired result immediately follows.

Appendix: Degenerate BioCro systems

This appendix is meant to demonstrate certain edge cases and ‚Äúoff-label‚Äù uses of BioCro systems. All of these systems are set up using the R interface. A similar set of systems that use the C++ library directly could be written in C++.

A minimal system

This system contains the absolute minimum number of quantities. Since it has only a single time point, timestep is present only to satisfy a formal requirement of the validity checker; it is otherwise meaningless.

A formal requirement of the R interface (but not of the C++ interface) is that the set of driver variables either contains time or contains both doy and hour. In the latter case, time will automatically be calculated from doy and hour.

library(BioCro)
run_biocro(parameters = list(timestep=1), drivers = data.frame(time=45.625))
##   ncalls   time
## 1      1 45.625
run_biocro(parameters = list(timestep=1), drivers = data.frame(doy=80, hour=14.25))
##   doy fractional_doy  hour ncalls    time
## 1  80       80.59375 14.25      1 1910.25

Note that ncalls always shows up in the output data frame, even though it is constant and even though it is not a system variable.

Note also that if time is a driver, it dominates: doy and hour (if present) are overwritten. If time is not present, both doy and hour must be; if only one is, time cannot be calculated and we get an error:

run_biocro(
    parameters = list(timestep=1),
    differential_module_names = 'BioCro:harmonic_oscillator',
    drivers = data.frame(doy=80)
)
## Error: No `time` variable found in the `drivers` dataframe.

A system having a differential variable but no differential module

As noted in Section , it is the initial_values parameter that determines which variables are differential variables. Usually, each differential variable will be an output of one or more differential modules, but this is not required. Differential variables that are not in the output of any differential module are assumed to have a derivative of zero; that is, they are constant. This system exhibits such a case.

run_biocro(initial_values = list(x = 52),
           parameters = list(timestep=1),
           drivers = data.frame(time=0:4))
##   ncalls time  x
## 1      5    0 52
## 2      5    1 52
## 3      5    2 52
## 4      5    3 52
## 5      5    4 52

An off-label use of run_biocro

Here is an example of what might be called an ‚Äúoff-label‚Äù use of a BioCro system. This system really doesn‚Äôt deserve to be called a dynamical system at all. Although the drivers parameter contains five rows of temporal and spacial data (each row specifies a time and a place), the rows have no inherent relationship to one another: they do not represent any sort of evolution of a system over time. The times specified by the rows aren‚Äôt even in chronological order: although the timestep variable is supposed to indicate the temporal relationship between successive rows of the drivers parameter value, this is a convention only, and it is not enforced.

Nevertheless, this system is useful: it uses the BioCro:solar_position_michalsky module to compute the cosine of the zenith angle of the sun at noon in various terrestrial locations on various days of the year. We could have gotten the same information using five calls to run_biocro with drivers having a single row, but doing it in one call is more convenient.

result <- run_biocro(parameters = list(timestep=1),
                     drivers = data.frame(doy = c(355, 172, 80, 80, 80),
                                          hour = 12,
                                          time_zone_offset = -6,
                                          year = 2022,
                                          lat = c(40, 40, 40, 0, 89),
                                          longitude = -88),
                     direct_module_names = 'BioCro:solar_position_michalsky')
result[c('lat', 'longitude', 'doy', 'hour', 'cosine_zenith_angle')]
##   lat longitude doy hour cosine_zenith_angle
## 1  40       -88 355   12          0.44655908
## 2  40       -88 172   12          0.95824629
## 3  40       -88  80   12          0.77093280
## 4   0       -88  80   12          0.99996308
## 5  89       -88  80   12          0.02509952

A system having only drivers (and the obligatory timestep parameter)

Like the minimal system shown in the first example, this system has no differential variables and no modules. But the drivers include some driver variables that aren‚Äôt time related. Like all systems not having any modules, it doesn‚Äôt really do anything.

result <- run_biocro(parameters = list(timestep=1),
                     drivers = weather$`2005`[1000:1010,])
result[c('year', 'doy', 'hour', 'precip', 'rh', 'solar', 'temp', 'windspeed')]
##    year doy hour precip   rh solar  temp windspeed
## 1  2005  42   15 0.0106 0.74   756 4.530      7.48
## 2  2005  42   16 0.0106 0.70   421 5.080      7.45
## 3  2005  42   17 0.0106 0.73   102 4.370      5.94
## 4  2005  42   18 0.0106 0.80     1 2.460      4.78
## 5  2005  42   19 0.0106 0.83     0 1.650      4.12
## 6  2005  42   20 0.0106 0.84     0 1.210      3.57
## 7  2005  42   21 0.0106 0.87     0 0.635      3.26
## 8  2005  42   22 0.0106 0.86     0 0.550      3.76
## 9  2005  42   23 0.0106 0.85     0 0.890      4.82
## 10 2005  43    0 0.0000 0.82     0 1.250      4.96
## 11 2005  43    1 0.0000 0.83     0 1.030      5.67

The weather information this run displays could just as easily be displayed using

weather$`2005`[1000:1010,
               c('year', 'doy', 'hour', 'precip', 'rh', 'solar', 'temp', 'windspeed')]
